description: From Middle English lebord, leburd, probably from Old Norse *hléborð, equivalent to lee +‎ board. Cognate with Icelandic hléborð.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A board, or frame of planks, lowered over the side of a sailboat to lessen its leeway.
examples: […]  on the port side a sofa bed was put up and fitted with a leeboard. On the starboard side a short seat with a folding cot above, which folded  […]

entries.meaning: (uncommon) Port, larboard (the side of a ship opposite starboard).
examples: Even in complete reversals from starboard to leeboard in a high sea, no shocks, either electrical or mechanical, could be observed.
